json.text: hi guys now you know you need to take the IELTS exam and you know what score
you need to achieve the question is where do you start your preparation
today I will share with you a five-step study plan that will help you to learn
all the must-knows about the IELTS exam and I believe that everyone needs to
know these before taking the exam I've also prepared a downloadable PDF file
linking to all the materials I'm gonna mention in this video and I will tell
you where to get it a bit later now let's talk about the first step step one
is to learn the test structure find out what types of tasks you can get during
the exam how it's better to distribute your time between different tasks and also
what are the best strategies for approaching each task where can you get
this information to learn more about the test format you can go on official IELTS
websites such as British Council and IELTS.org and just read it it's a bit more
difficult to get all the tips in one place there are lots of sources but I've
recently made a video covering the test format and the tips on each section and
if you haven't seen it yet I'm gonna link it in the corner of the screen and
after the video as well it's 23 minutes long but it's packed with useful
information okay now let's go to step two take practice tests there are
official practice tests and unofficial practice tests from various
organisations and I prefer official tests for two reasons
first the level of difficulty is exactly the same as you'll face on the exam day
and the second reason is the tasks are as close to the real thing as possible
two official practice tests are available for free and you can find them on the
British Council and IELTS.org websites I'm gonna link them in my study plan
take those tests and if you feel that you need more practice then you can buy
a book like this these are official practice exams from Cambridge English
Assessment that's a part of the University of Cambridge which actually
writes IELTS exams and you can get a book for IELTS academic like this one or
a very similar book for IELTS general training each book includes four tests
and all the answers number 12 in the latest edition what I particularly like in
this book is that you can also find model answers for the writing tasks with
comments from the examiner and band scores and you can see which essays get a
band score five or six or seven and then you can compare your essays to those and
you will see where approximately you are at this moment because other model
answers are usually amazing but that's not what people actually write during
the exam and it's important to understand what you need to achieve on
the day step three is to understand how your IELTS exam is marked virtually
nobody achieves band 9 in all four components of the test native speakers
don't do that IELTS tutors who are native speakers struggle to do that so
don't think that you need to answer every question correctly it's only a
matter of how many mistakes you can actually make to achieve the band score
you need for example in the reading and the listening section you need to answer
30 questions out of 40 to get band 7 and band 7 is a very good score here is a
table where you can see how many questions you actually need to answer
correctly if you'd like to study it pause the video now okay let's continue
the scoring in the writing and the speaking sections is not as
straightforward and that's especially true for
IELTS writing basically your grammar and vocabulary together give you 50% of the
mark and the other 50% depend on how well you structure your essay how you
develop and support your ideas and how well you link sentences together so all
those things don't come naturally to most people they definitely don't come
naturally to me and you really need to know what the criteria are in order to
fulfill them all these requirements are described in the IELTS band descriptors
documents which are available publicly you can see them on the screen now and
as you can see for each score you have separate requirements it will take
longer to study those documents so I'm gonna link them in the study plan and
it's a good idea to learn those requirements well in order to achieve
a good score in IELTS writing step 4 is to learn best strategies for each task
and let's continue talking about IELTS writing the typical difficulties here are
to finish both essays within 60 minutes and to write more words than required it's
actually not easy to do and to succeed in IELTS writing you need to finish both
essays so you need to write quickly that's why I suggest learning the
structure for each task very well if you know what exactly you need to write in
your introduction in your body paragraphs in your conclusion that's for
task 2 and an overview/summary for task 1 you'll be able to write a bit more
quickly and that's very important if we're talking about IELTS academic then
task 1 requires describing a map a diagram a chart and to do that you need
words which we don't normally use every day so it's a good idea to learn several
dozens words specifically for this task I made a
list of basic words to start with and I'll link it in the study plan as usual
for the writing task 2 and the speaking section try to find lists of typical
tasks and topics which are frequently used in IELTS and think what would you
write or what would you say if you got this topic during the exam
obviously you can't write a practice essay on each topic it would take a
million of time but just think what would you write having some ideas in
your head during the exam already helps in the reading section there are two
main strategies the first one is to read the whole passage first and then answer
questions for me personally this strategy doesn't work because by the
time I go to the questions I've already forgotten what I've read and I have to
go back and find the answer and also in IELTS they don't ask questions which
are very generic questions are specific and quite often I need to go back to the
text find the sentence reread it and then answer the question so it takes
extra time so what I do is I read the question and then I try to find the
answer next question next answer and so on and continue because for many tasks
in IELTS reading you can find answers in the text in the same order as the
questions are asked so it simplifies things a bit but I know that some people
still prefer to stick to the first strategy and what you need to do is to
try both choose the one that works for you and stick to it the main challenge
of the listening section is to listen to the recording read questions and write
down answers all at the same time there will be only short breaks between
different dialogues in the listening section when you can
read questions which are coming but quite often there is not enough time to
read all of them so you really need to manage your time and your attention
during the listening section very very effectively and you will not have time
to figure out what the task is and what you actually need to do so you need to
know each type of task really really well not to spend a second of your time
on figuring out the tasks only concentrating on reading the questions
and anticipating answers if you don't do that you may be cut out by the speed of
this test even if your English skills are very good and you can understand
every word in the recording step 5 is to practice difficult tasks what tasks are
the most difficult in IELTS you will find it for yourself and it obviously
depends on your skills maybe you speak a lot in English or
maybe you read a lot well there are a few types of tasks which require special
attention in the reading section these are true false not given questions when
you need to say if a certain statement is true false or information wasn't
provided in the text and you can't say if it's true or false
I find this questions very tricky because they require not only your
English skills but also verbal reasoning skills and actually in the UK
when I was looking for a job after graduation many big companies sent me
similar tests they are called aptitude tests to check analytical abilities so that's
what you need to have in order to succeed in this type of task and it's
really worth practicing in advance and when you check answers and you see that
you've got the question wrong go back to the text try to find the answer and
understand why it's true or why it's not given next time it will be a bit easier
to answer such questions a very similar type of question is yes
now not given when you need to say if the author of this text agrees with a
statement disagrees all the information is not provided in the listening section
there are questions about maps so you will see a map and there will be gaps
and you need to listen to the recording and feel in gaps I find these questions
particularly easy to miss because once you miss a couple of words beforehand
you may not understand about what place on the map they are talking about and
then you miss the next question so it really requires high concentration
another type of task is when you need to choose between three options the
difficulty is the question is quite long and three options are also quite long
each almost a sentence long and then you have five questions like that and it's
actually a lot of reading and you don't have enough time to carefully read all
the questions and all options and then the recording starts and they will
mention all three options in the speech but only one will be correct so I think
that these tasks really require some practice I've included links to all the
materials I mentioned in this video in the downloadable PDF file and you can
get it in the video description below and if you like this video please don't
forget to like it and subscribe to the channel for more IELTS preparation
videos and if you haven't seen my video about IELTS strategies and tips on how
to approach each section of the test you can watch it now thank you so much for
watching this video today and good luck with your preparation bye
